description: From Middle English copies, from Old French copeiz (“a cut-over forest”), from presumed Vulgar Latin *colpaticium (“having the quality of being cut”), from *colpāre (“to cut, strike”), from *colpus (“a blow”), from Latin colaphus (“a cuff, box on the ear”), from Ancient Greek κόλαφος (kólaphos, “a blow, slap”).

entries.meaning: A grove of small growth; a thicket of brushwood; a wood cut at certain times for fuel or other purposes, typically managed to promote growth and ensure a reliable supply of timber. See copse.
examples: It was also enacted that all coppices or underwoods should be enclosed for periods from four to seven years after felling.

verbs.description: coppice (third-person singular simple present coppices, present participle coppicing, simple past and past participle coppiced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To manage (a wooded area) sustainably, as a coppice, by periodically cutting back woody plants to promote new growth.
examples: Her plan to coppice the woods should keep her self-sufficient in fuel indefinitely.
